Without reforms that reduce costs and delays for homebuilders, Metro’s housing crisis will continue.Article contentArticle contentArticle contentTo illustrate the scale of the problem, consider what buying a home in Metro looks like for a middle-income family. According to a new study published by the Fraser Institute, in 2023 (the latest year of comparable data), the annual median after-tax income for a family in Metro was $64,660 while the price of a typical home —  meaning a home of any type (detached, townhouse, condo, etc.) with common characteristics and amenities — was $1.17 million.Article contentThere was an error, please provide a valid email address.Sign UpThanks for signing up!A welcome email is on its way. Browse here.Article contentThat means a family had to save $238,240 — equal to more than 3 1/2 years of its after-tax income — for a 20 per cent down payment on a typical home.Article contentBut even after this massive down payment, the monthly mortgage payment ($6,052) would cost more than the family’s entire monthly after-tax income.Article contentObviously, for many families, buying a typical home is impossible.Article contentFor those priced out of home ownership, renting has offered little relief. Metro was Canada’s second least-affordable area for renters in 2023 (again, the latest year of comparable data), with the median rental unit costing $1,715 per month — or 31.8 per cent of the median after-tax family income — up from $1,035 (26.3 per cent) a decade earlier in 2014.Article contentArticle contentAnd there’s more bad news. While the recent decline in house prices hasn’t been enough to meaningfully improve affordability, it has made it harder for builders to cover their costs, prompting a steep contraction in homebuilding at a time when the city needs more new homes.Article contentRead More

These policies add costs and delays that deter homebuilding, especially when falling prices are already squeezing developer margins.Article contentOf course, some factors remain beyond the control of local policy-makers.Article contentFor example, federal immigration policy, particularly over the last five years, has greatly increased demand for homes in the Lower Mainland and across Canada.Article contentBut here’s a fact — builders would build more homes in Metro, despite falling prices, if not for lengthy approval processes and costly government fees. To help improve housing affordability in Metro, municipalities in the district must remove unnecessary barriers to development.Article contentTegan Hill and Austin Thompson are analysts at the Fraser Institute.Article contentShare this article in your social network
